choices.text: High HDV viral load
High HBV viral load
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text:
Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below: (INICET NOV 2022)

  • HBsAg positive
  • Anti-HBc IgM positive
  • Anti-HDV IgM positive
  • Anti-HBc IgG negative
  • Titer of HBV DNA: 7.4 x 10⁸
  • Titer of HDV DNA: 4.1 x 10⁴

Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies

 

Anti-HBc IgG antibodies are markers of chronic hepatitis B infection. Their presence along with anti-HDV antibodies would suggest a superinfection of hepatitis D virus (HDV) on top of chronic hepatitis B infection.

 

The absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies indicates an acute episode of hepatitis B, which suggests HBV/HDV co-infection. Co-infection occurs when a person is simultaneously infected with both HBV and HDV, leading to acute hepatitis with signs and symptoms such as fatigue, jaundice, and dark urine. Co-infection typically resolves with recovery and viral eradication in most cases.

 

In contrast, HDV superinfection occurs when an individual who is already chronically infected with HBV acquires HDV. Superinfection tends to result in more severe disease progression, and the absence of anti-HBc IgG helps differentiate co-infection from superinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: The viral load of HDV can be elevated in both co-infection and superinfection, making it not a reliable marker for distinguishing between the two conditions.

 

Option B. High HBV viral load: HBV viral load is not the most relevant marker in distinguishing between co-infection and superinfection, as it may vary depending on the phase of infection and other factors. HBV viral load can be high in both conditions.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: The presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies indicates a recent or ongoing HDV infection, but it does not differentiate between co-infection and superinfection since both can result in the production of these antibodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of hepatitis B and D, the absence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies indicates an acute co-infection of HBV and HDV. This finding helps distinguish co-infection from superinfection, which typically occurs in patients with chronic HBV infection and is marked by the presence of anti-HBc IgG antibodies. Co-infection generally has a better prognosis compared to superinfection, which is more likely to lead to chronic disease and cirrhosis.

questions.text: A female with breast cancer undergoes investigation which reveals the presence of ER positivity. Presence of ER is important as it is a:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Predictive marker

 

Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity in breast cancer is primarily used as a predictive marker. The presence of ER indicates that the cancer cells are likely to respond to hormonal therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. These therapies work by blocking estrogen receptors or decreasing estrogen levels in the body, which helps slow or stop the growth of ER-positive breast cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic marker: The presence of ER is not used to diagnose breast cancer, as normal breast tissue can also express estrogen receptors. Therefore, ER positivity alone cannot confirm a diagnosis of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Prognostic marker: While ER status can provide some prognostic information, such as indicating a potentially better outcome due to responsiveness to hormone therapy, it is not solely used for prognosis. Prognostic factors typically include tumor size, lymph node status, and other molecular markers.

 

Option D. Surrogate molecular marker: A surrogate molecular marker is used as a substitute for a clinical endpoint. ER positivity does not serve as a surrogate molecular marker in this context; instead, it directly informs the treatment approach and potential response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER positivity in breast cancer is a predictive marker that helps determine the likelihood of response to hormonal therapies, making it crucial for guiding treatment decisions.

 

Additional classification:

questions.text: Which of the following has protective as well as lubricating property? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucin

 

Mucins form a protective barrier on epithelial surfaces. They are also found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory and urogenital tract. They also have lubricating properties.

 

Functions of Mucin:

  1. Membrane-bound mucins participate in various cell-cell interactions.
  2. Protective barrier on epithelial surfaces.
  3. Lubricating properties.
  4. "Mask" certain surface antigens.
  5. Mucins also carry cancer-specific peptide and carbohydrate epitopes.

 

Salient features of Mucin:

  1. Found in secretions of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and reproductive tracts and also in membranes of various cells.
  2. Exhibit high content of O-glycan chains, usually containing NeuAc.
  3. Contain repeating amino acid sequences rich in serine, threonine, and proline.
  4. Extended structure contributes to their high viscoelasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collagen: Collagen provides structural support and strength to tissues but does not have significant lubricating properties.

 

Option C. Albumin: Albumin is a major plasma protein involved in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting various substances but does not have lubricating properties.

 

Option D. Immunoglobulin: Immunoglobulins are antibodies that play a crucial role in immune response but do not provide lubrication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucins have both protective and lubricating properties, forming a barrier on epithelial surfaces and reducing friction in various body tracts. They are essential for maintaining the integrity and function of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents with altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, and bradycardia. Examination revealed non-pitting edema of the extremities. She has a long-standing history of weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myxedema coma

 

The patient presents with several symptoms indicative of severe hypothyroidism. These include altered sensorium, breathlessness, hypotension, bradycardia, non-pitting edema, weight gain, constipation, cold intolerance, and menorrhagia. In hypothyroid patients, a severe, life-threatening condition called myxedema coma can develop. This is characterized by a profound deficiency of thyroid hormones, leading to critical manifestations such as altered mental status, hypothermia, bradycardia, hypotension, and edema.

 

Myxedema coma requires immediate medical intervention. The treatment of choice involves intravenous administration of thyroxine (IV T4) and IV hydrocortisone. IV hydrocortisone is essential because many patients with myxedema coma have subtle adrenal insufficiency, which can become overt with the initiation of thyroid hormone replacement. This combination helps stabilize the patient's condition and addresses both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic shock: While this condition involves hypotension and altered sensorium, it is usually associated with signs of infection, fever, and a source of sepsis, which are not described in this patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: This condition involves heart failure and typically presents with signs of fluid overload, severe breathlessness, and possibly chest pain, none of which are noted in this patient’s history.

 

Option D. Hyperthyroidism: The symptoms of hyperthyroidism include weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, and increased bowel movements, which are opposite to the symptoms exhibited by this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening condition of profound hypothyroidism, characterized by symptoms such as altered sensorium, bradycardia, hypotension, and non-pitting edema. Immediate treatment involves IV thyroxine and IV hydrocortisone to manage both thyroid and potential adrenal insufficiency

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.

 

Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.

 

Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: Detoxification of Xenobiotics for phase 1 reaction (Hydroxylation) require monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 along with: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH

 

The detoxification of xenobiotics in phase 1 reactions, particularly hydroxylation reactions catalyzed by monooxygenases or cytochrome P-450 enzymes, requires reducing equivalents in the form of NADPH. NADPH serves as a cofactor that provides electrons for the enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NADH: NADH is not the primary cofactor used in phase 1 hydroxylation reactions.

 

Option C. FAD: FAD (Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide) is not typically involved in the hydroxylation reactions of xenobiotic detoxification in phase 1.

 

Option D. FADH2: Similar to FAD, FADH2 is not the primary cofactor required for the hydroxylation reactions involved in the detoxification of xenobiotics during phase 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this reaction, a xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor. The cytochrome P450 enzyme catalyzes this reaction, leading to the introduction of a hydroxyl group into the xenobiotic molecule, making it more water-soluble and facilitating subsequent conjugation reactions in phase 2 detoxification.

questions.text:
You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence.

 

  1. Lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
  3. SDS-PAGE
  4. Hybridization
  5. Protein elution/extraction
  6. Expression of protein

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

 

Explanation:

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:

 

  1. b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  2. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  3. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  4. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  5. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  6. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

References: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 432-438

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period
Beta HCG estimation
Serum FSH and LH

questions.text: A patient has been on MALA-N for 6 months. She is compliant, but she complained of missed periods. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

MALA-N is a combined oral contraceptive pill (OCP). Despite high compliance, all contraceptive methods have a failure rate. The first consideration for a missed period in a woman of reproductive age is pregnancy. Therefore, the next step is to estimate beta HCG levels to rule out pregnancy.

 

  • Beta HCG Estimation: This is essential to confirm or rule out pregnancy. Serum beta HCG can detect pregnancy as early as five days before the first missed period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This is not the initial step. It is more appropriate once pregnancy is confirmed or other issues are suspected.

 

Option B. Reassure her that it's normal to have a delayed period: While some irregularity can occur with OCPs, pregnancy must be ruled out first.

 

Option D. Serum FSH and LH: These tests are used to evaluate ovarian function but are not appropriate for initial evaluation of a missed period in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a woman on combined oral contraceptive pills presents with a missed period, the first step is to rule out pregnancy by estimating beta HCG levels.

 

Ref: Page no 622, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
Match the following with regards to cellular inclusions: 

 

Column-A

1. Howell-Jolly bodies

2. Dohle bodies

3. Flame cells

4. Auer rod cells

 

Column-B

a. Ig inclusions

b. Azurophilic granules

c. Nuclear material remnants

d. Remnants of ER
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 → c, 2 → d, 3 → a, 4 → b

 

1. Howell-Jolly bodies → Nuclear material remnants (c): Howell-Jolly bodies are remnants of nuclear material within red blood cells, seen in cases of asplenia or when the spleen's filtering function is impaired.

 

 

2. Dohle bodies → Remnants of ER (d): Döhle bodies are blue inclusions in neutrophils, representing remnants of the endoplasmic reticulum. They appear in conditions like sepsis and severe inflammatory states.

 

 

3. Flame cells → Ig inclusions (a): Flame cells are plasma cells with red-staining cytoplasm due to immunoglobulin accumulation, seen in certain plasma cell disorders.

 

 

4. Auer rod cells → Azurophilic granules (b): Auer rods are azurophilic, rod-like structures found in the cytoplasm of myeloblasts, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants in RBCs, indicating asplenia.
  • Dohle bodies: Remnants of ER, seen in neutrophils during severe inflammation.
  • Flame cells: Plasma cells with Ig inclusions.
  • Auer rods: Azurophilic granules in myeloblasts, seen in AML.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Image 3

 

The shows an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy. Barium swallow reveals an apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 3.

 

In contrast to adenocarcinoma, half of squamous cell carcinomas occur in the middle third of the esophagus. Squamous cell carcinoma begins as an in-situ lesion termed squamous dysplasia (this lesion is referred to as intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ at other sites). Early lesions appear as small, gray-white, plaque-like thickenings. Over months to years, they grow into tumor masses that may be polypoid or exophytic and protrude into and obstruct the lumen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the esophagus and is characterized histologically by nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, as seen in Image 3.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

 

CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.

 

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.

 

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.

 

It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Line probe assay: Line probe assay is another molecular diagnostic test used for detecting resistance to first-line and second-line anti-TB drugs. However, it is not the first choice for initial diagnosis following a negative sputum smear but suggestive chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Liquid culture: Liquid culture is used for confirming TB diagnosis and drug susceptibility testing. It is more time-consuming compared to molecular tests like CBNAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly associated with a hypercoagulable state? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor V mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability. It should be suspected in young patients (<50 years) presenting with thrombotic manifestations.

 

  • It is caused by substitution in the Factor V gene (Factor V Leiden mutation)
  • Causes enhanced coagulability in patients
  • In heterozygous condition, increases risk of thrombus formation by 4-5 times
  • In homozygous condition, increases risk by 50 times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antithrombin III deficiency 

 

  • Although this can cause thrombosis, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation
  • Antithrombin III acts as a natural anticoagulant
  • Its deficiency is rarer compared to Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Option C. Factor XIII deficiency

 

  • Factor XIII is involved in clot stabilization
  • Its deficiency causes bleeding rather than thrombosis
  • Characterized by umbilical cord bleeding in newborns

 

Option D. Factor XII deficiency 

 

  • Factor XII initiates intrinsic pathway of coagulation
  • Its deficiency does not cause significant bleeding
  • Not typically associated with hypercoagulable states

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable states, increasing thrombosis risk 4-5 times in heterozygous and 50 times in homozygous individuals.

questions.text: Addison's disease is commonly associated with: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autoimmune adrenalitis

 

Addison's disease, primarily characterized by adrenal insufficiency, is most commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system attacks the adrenal cortex, leading to a decrease in the production of steroid hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypernephroma: Also known as renal cell carcinoma, hypernephroma is a type of kidney cancer and has no direct link to the adrenal function or Addison's disease.

 

Option C. Adrenocortical carcinoma: This is a cancer of the adrenal cortex but typically leads to excessive hormone production, associated more with Cushing's syndrome rather than Addison's disease, where there is hormone deficiency.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid: This type of cancer is associated with the thyroid gland and is related to multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome but not directly linked to Addison's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is most commonly caused by autoimmune adrenalitis, where the immune system mistakenly attacks the adrenal glands, leading to insufficient production of vital hormones.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with HRT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been shown to decrease the risk of colon cancer. HRT is often used to manage symptoms of menopause, such as hot flushes and osteoporosis, but it also has some protective effects, including lowering the risk of colon cancer.

 

  • Indications of HRT:
    • Therapeutic: For symptomatic women with estrogen deficiency or specific conditions like gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents.
    • Prophylactic: It is used in high-risk cases, such as preventing menopausal complications like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s, and colon cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This is incorrect. HRT, especially when combined (estrogen and progesterone), has been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen therapy (without progesterone) increases the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This is incorrect. HRT actually reduces the risk of osteoporosis, as estrogen helps maintain bone density.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer but is associated with an increased risk of breast and endometrial cancers.

questions.text: Which is not an obvious advantage of high-flow nasal cannula? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases need of intubation

 

Explanation:

 

 

  • Decreases need of intubation: While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can be an intermediate step between standard oxygen therapy and more invasive respiratory support, it doesn't always eliminate the need for intubation. HFNC can improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing in many patients, but it may not be sufficient in cases of severe respiratory failure where intubation becomes necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: High-flow nasal cannula allows for the delivery of oxygen at much higher flow rates than standard nasal cannulae. This higher flow rate can flush out the nasopharyngeal dead space, leading to a more consistent fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and improving alveolar ventilation.

 

Option C. Heating and humidification: One of the distinct features of HFNC systems is that they deliver oxygen that's both heated and humidified. This enhances comfort, reduces the risk of mucosal drying and injury, and can help improve mucociliary clearance.

 

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): PEEP refers to the maintenance of a positive pressure in the airways at the end of expiration, which can prevent alveolar collapse. The high flow rate from HFNC can generate a degree of PEEP, especially with the mouth closed. This can help recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation in certain patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) offers several advantages, including reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, providing heated and humidified oxygen, and generating PEEP, it does not always eliminate the need for intubation in patients with severe respiratory failure.

choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: Match the following: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Uro bags - collection of urine.
  • An underwater seal bag- collection of drainage fluid from the thoracic cavity.
  • Nasogastric tube / Ryle's tube - Used for Nasogastric feeding / Stomach wash / Aspiration
  • Metallic suction cannula - To clear the operative field by suctioning secretions/blood

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the appropriate explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are correct, but the Reason is not the explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is correct, but the Reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect, but the Reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: Menopause is associated with hot flashes.


Reason: Hot flashes occur because of a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen levels.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are correct, and the Reason is the appropriate explanation for the Assertion

 

Menopause is closely associated with hot flashes, which are sudden and brief sensations of heat that can cause redness and sweating, particularly affecting the face and neck. These episodes typically last from 2 to 5 minutes. The frequency can vary, but they are usually more pronounced during nighttime, causing significant sleep disturbances.

 

The physiological explanation for hot flashes centers around hormonal changes, specifically a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen. Estrogen is crucial for the proper functioning of the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center, which maintains the body's temperature. During menopause, the drop in estrogen levels results in a decrease in hypothalamic endorphins. This decline leads to an increase in neurotransmitters like norepinephrine and serotonin. The surge in norepinephrine disrupts the hypothalamus's ability to regulate body temperature effectively, triggering episodes of hot flashes.

 

Common symptoms that accompany hot flashes include:

 

  • Headaches
  • Palpitations
  • Chest discomfort (anginal pains)
  • Irritability
  • Difficulty concentrating

 

Although estrogen deficiency is a major cause of hot flashes, it is essential to note that there are other potential causes. These include thyroid issues, epilepsy, tumors like pheochromocytoma and insulinomas, carcinoid syndromes, autoimmune diseases, and some blood disorders like leukemias. This highlights the complexity of diagnosing and understanding hot flashes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hot flashes during menopause are caused by a decrease or fluctuation in estrogen, which disrupts the thermoregulatory system in the hypothalamus, leading to sudden heat sensations and sweating.

questions.text: What should be the ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4%

 

Explanation:

 

  • Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
  • As per the strict criteria, >4% normal forms of morphology must be present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis is >4% according to WHO 2010 criteria.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg442, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

questions.text: Which curve among the following represents the production of gamma-globin chains?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Orange curve

 

In the given image, the orange curve represents the gamma-globin chain production.

 

 

Gamma globin chain is produced in the fetal period and disappears by 6 months of age. Postpartum which is the pattern represented by the orange curve.

 

The type of hemoglobin variant is determined by the combination of globin chains.

Adult hemoglobin consists of 2 alpha and 2 beta chains, whereas fetal hemoglobin is made of 2 alpha and 2 gamma-globin chains. ﻿

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green Curve: Incorrect. The green curve represents beta-globin chain production, which increases after birth and replaces gamma-globin chains in adult hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Black Curve: Incorrect. The black curve does not accurately represent any specific globin chain production in this context.

 

Option C. Blue Curve: Incorrect. The blue curve represents epsilon-globin chain production, which occurs during the embryonic stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The orange curve in the provided image represents the production of gamma-globin chains, which are crucial during the fetal period and decline after birth as beta-globin production increases.

choices.text: Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known history of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus presents to the emergency department with symptoms of increased thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, and confusion. On examination, the child appears dehydrated and is breathing rapidly. Laboratory tests reveal a blood glucose level of 400 mg/dl and blood gas analysis is indicative of acidosis. Initial treatment with intravenous fluids has been started. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer normal saline for the first hour followed by insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is an acute, life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus that typically requires IV fluids and insulin administration to correct hyperglycemia and halt ketogenesis. According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour. 

Other options:

Option B. Give an insulin stat dose of 0.1 units/kg intravenously, followed by an infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: According to new guidelines, bolus dose of insulin is not used for treatment of DKA particularly in children as it increases the risk of cerebral edema in many children.

 

Option A. Initiate an insulin intravenous infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin infusion is an essential part of DKA management, according to new guidelines, it's typically given one hour after the adminsitration of IV fluids.

 

Option D. Continue with intravenous fluids without insulin administration: This would not address the hyperglycemia and ketosis and is therefore inadequate for the treatment of DKA.

 

Educational Objective:

According to latest guidelines for management of DKA in children first IV fulids are administered for one hour, then insulin is adminsitered by IV infusion at a rate of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Hall-Wellner Band

 

  • The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a graphical representation commonly used in survival analysis to display the probability of an event, typically survival, over time.
  • It is particularly useful when studying the time to a specific event, such as death or disease progression.
  • The Kaplan-Meier curve often incorporates bands around the survival estimate, which represent the confidence interval.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, Gill bands, and Nair's Equal Precision confidence bands are used for this purpose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unequal precision band: Not a standard term used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option B. Hirshberg band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option C. Holmes band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Confabulation
  2. Amnesia
  3. Peripheral neuropathy
  4. Ophthalmoplegia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder most commonly caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). It is often associated with alcohol misuse, but can also be caused by other conditions. The primary features of Korsakoff syndrome include:

 

1. Confabulation: Patients often create false memories or stories to fill in gaps in their memory. These are not intentional lies, but rather attempts to make sense of their memory loss.

 

2. Amnesia: This involves significant memory impairment. Anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) is more prominent than retrograde amnesia (difficulty recalling past memories).

 

3. Peripheral neuropathy: This is also seen in Korsakoff syndrome, involving nerve damage that can cause pain, numbness, or weakness, typically in the hands and feet.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Ophthalmoplegia: This is not a feature of Korsakoff syndrome. Ophthalmoplegia, or paralysis of the eye muscles, is a characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome but is a separate condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Kidney
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.

 

In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

3 and 4: While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells  

 

Isotype switching is seen in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching: Conversion of one antibody class (isotype) to another resulting from the genetic rearrangement of heavy-chain constant-region genes in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching is dependent on the presence of both antigens and cytokines secreted by T-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: While Helper T cells (especially Th2 cells) provide the necessary cytokines that drive isotype switching in B cells, they themselves do not undergo isotype switching.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells and do not produce antibodies or undergo isotype switching.

 

Option D. Naive B cells: Naive B cells, which have not yet encountered their specific antigen, initially produce IgM and IgD. They do not undergo isotype switching until after activation by an antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching is a process that occurs in activated B cells, allowing them to produce different classes of antibodies to effectively combat various types of pathogens.

choices.text: 50 mg
30.5 mg
12.5 mg

questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)?  (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 30.5 mg

 

This question can be solved by two methods.

 

Method 1: Using the fraction method

In 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.

75 mg is excreted in 90 mins.

Therefore 75/200 = 3/8th of the drug is eliminated in 90 minutes.

Thus after 90 minutes, 1-3/8 = 5/8th portion of the drug is left behind.

6 hours = 4 * 90 minutes.

Or, in 6 hrs = (5/8) * (5/8) *(5/8)*(5/8)* 200 mg will be left behind

= 30.518 mg will be left behind.

 

Method 2: Using the formula

First we need to determine the elimination rate constant (k) and the half-life (t1/2) of the drug.

We know that 75 mg of the drug is excreted in 90 minutes (1.5 hours). This means that the amount remaining after 1.5 hours is 200 mg - 75 mg = 125 mg.

First, we can use the formula for first-order kinetics to find k:

k = {log (C0/Ct)} / t​

Where:

  • C0 ​is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • Ct ​is the concentration after time t (125 mg)
  • t is the time in hours (1.5 hours)

k = {log⁡ (200/125)} / 1.5

k={log⁡(1.6)} / 1.5

k ≈ 0.470/1.5

k ≈ 0.313 hr−1

Next, we find the half-life using the relationship between k and t1/2:

t1/2 = 0.693 /k

t1/2 ​= 0.693​/0.313

t1/2 = 2.21 hours

Now, we need to determine the amount of drug left after 6 hours. We use the first-order kinetics formula:

Ct = C0 × e−kt

Where:

  • C0 is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • k is the elimination rate constant (0.313 hr^-1)
  • t is the time (6 hours)

Ct = 200 × e−0.313×6

Ct = 200 × e−1.878

Ct = 200 × 0.153

Ct ≈ 30.5 mg

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis.

 

Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

 

The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B
  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.
  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.
  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 33 page no 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tangier’s disease

 

Tangier's disease is an inherited disorder characterized by significantly reduced levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. This condition can lead to the accumulation of cholesterol in various tissues and organs. Individuals with Tangier's disease may have enlarged orange tonsils and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease as shown in the picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wolman's Disease: Wolman's disease is a severe form of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) deficiency, a rare genetic disorder. It is characterized by the complete absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid lipase, leading to the buildup of fats in various tissues and organs. Symptoms typically appear in infancy and may include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), splenomegaly (enlarged spleen), diarrhea/steatorrhea (fatty stools), and vomiting. This condition can be life-threatening.

 

Option B. Gaucher's Disease: Gaucher's disease is another genetic disorder caused by the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. It results in the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucocerebroside in various organs and tissues, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Common symptoms include an enlarged spleen and liver, anemia, low platelet counts, and bone abnormalities. There are different types of Gaucher's disease, and the severity can vary.

 

Option D. Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system. It is caused by the absence or deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, which leads to the buildup of a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside in the brain and nerve cells. Symptoms typically appear in early childhood and include developmental regression, loss of motor skills, and a cherry-red spot in the eye. Tay-Sachs disease is progressive and ultimately fatal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia

 

ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).

 

  • So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Enlarged lymph nodes
    • Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals. It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase

questions.text:
Match the following:

 

Column A:

A. Malaria
B. Tuberculosis
C. Leprosy
D. Actinomycosis

 

Column B:

1. ZN stain

2. Fite-Faraco stain

3. Gram stain

4. Giemsa stain
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

Option A. Malaria – Giemsa stain (4): Giemsa stain is the gold standard for malaria diagnosis. It helps visualize Maurer's clefts (seen in Plasmodium falciparum) and Schüffner's dots (seen in Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale).

 

Option B. Tuberculosis – ZN stain (1): Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain is used to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis, as it helps identify acid-fast bacilli in sputum samples.

 

Option C. Leprosy – Fite-Faraco stain (2): The Fite-Faraco stain is used to visualize Mycobacterium leprae, which causes leprosy. This stain highlights the acid-fastness of the bacillus with better sensitivity than the ZN stain for this organism.

 

Option D. Actinomycosis – Gram stain (3): Gram stain is typically used to identify Actinomyces, which are Gram-positive filamentous bacteria involved in actinomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each pathogen has a preferred staining method for its detection:

 

  • Giemsa stain for malaria (Plasmodium species).
  • Ziehl-Neelsen stain for tuberculosis (Mycobacterium tuberculosis).
  • Fite-Faraco stain for leprosy (Mycobacterium leprae).
  • Gram stain for actinomycosis (Actinomyces species).

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

When the surgeon returns the entire hernial sac to the abdominal cavity without reducing its contents, this procedure is known as "reduction en masse" of the hernia.

 

Reduction en-masse of inguinal hernia means reduction/migration of a hernial sac along with the incarcerated bowel into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Double loop of intestine is within a hernia sac with a tight neck.

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Organs like cecum (right) and sigmoid (left) accompany the sac and are present outside the sac.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia (irreducible).

choices.text: All are true
A, B and C only
A, C, and E only
A, B, D and E

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding foscarnet are True?

 

  1. It is used for resistant CMV infections
  2. Renal toxicity is seen
  3. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
  4. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required
  5. It can cause genital ulceration
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A, B, D and E

 

Foscarnet is an antiviral medication used primarily for the treatment of cytomegalovirus (CMV) and other herpesvirus infections, particularly when the viruses are resistant to other treatments like ganciclovir and acyclovir.

 

Statements:

 

A. It is used for resistant CMV infections

 

This is true. Foscarnet is effective against CMV, including strains that are resistant to ganciclovir.

 

B. Renal toxicity is seen

 

This is true. Renal toxicity is a significant adverse effect of foscarnet, which can lead to acute renal failure and other renal complications.

 

D. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

 

This is true. Due to its potential to cause electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypocalcemia, regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is necessary during foscarnet therapy.

 

E. It can cause genital ulceration

 

This is true. Genital ulceration is one of the potential side effects of foscarnet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase: This is false. Foscarnet does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase. Unlike acyclovir and ganciclovir, foscarnet directly inhibits viral DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase without needing to be phosphorylated by viral enzymes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus infection is acyclovir.
  • Drug of choice for cytomegalovirus is ganciclovir.
  • Both acyclovir and ganciclovir are pro-drugs and require activation by kinases.

 

FOSCARNET

 

  • It is a simple straight chain phosphonate.
  • It does not require activation by kinases.
  • It is active against H. simplex (including strains resistant to acyclovir), CMV (including ganciclovir-resistant ones) and other herpes group viruses.
  • Oral absorption is poor. Its t½ is 4–8 hours, and it is not metabolized by liver.
  • Toxicity of foscarnet is high. It damages kidney and produces a renal diabetes like condition; acute renal failure can also occur. Anemia, phlebitis, tremors, convulsions, genital ulceration and other neurological as well as constitutional symptoms due to hypocalcemia are frequent.
  • It is administered by i.v. infusion
     

Reference: KDT 8th/852, 853

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same core pathology except? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alzheimer’s disease

 

Alzheimer's disease is a 3-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein not an alpha-synucleinopathy.

 

Alpha-synucleinopathies:  A neurodegenerative disorders displaying an altered α-synuclein (αS) in the brain tissue and incorporates clinical entities such as Parkinson disease (PD), PD with dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, and multiple-system atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parkinson's disease: An alpha-synucleinopathy characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein in Lewy bodies within the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Lewy body dementia: Another alpha-synucleinopathy where alpha-synuclein aggregates are found in Lewy bodies within the cortical and subcortical areas of the brain.

 

Option D. Multisystem atrophy: A neurodegenerative disorder also categorized as an alpha-synucleinopathy, where alpha-synuclein accumulates in glial cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alzheimer's disease is characterized by the accumulation of β-amyloid and tau proteins, differentiating it from alpha-synucleinopathies like Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and multisystem atrophy.

choices.text: It may lead to pugilistic ear
It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space
All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented at the hospital with a reported history of ear trauma. Upon examination, there was observed swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Resolves spontaneously

 

The condition depicted in the image is perichondrial hematoma, commonly resulting from blunt trauma to the ear. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires medical intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the permanent deformity known as cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It may lead to pugilistic ear: This is true. If untreated, the hematoma can lead to fibrosis and calcification, causing a deformity known as cauliflower ear or pugilistic ear.

 

Option B. It is caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: True. The swelling and discoloration are due to blood accumulating in the perichondrial space, which separates the ear cartilage from the overlying skin.

 

Option D. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics: This is considered a good practice to prevent infection, especially since the ear's vascular supply is compromised, increasing the risk of perichondritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondrial hematoma does not resolve on its own and requires prompt medical treatment to prevent complications like infection and the formation of cauliflower ear. Management typically involves aspiration of the hematoma, application of a pressure dressing to maintain ear contour, and administration of prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses:

 

 

  1. Severe dehydration
  2. HUS
  3. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
  4. Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

The differential diagnoses in a child with a history of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia.

 

The lack of dysentery (bloody diarrhea) and the short period of interval between diarrheal episodes and the symptom complex help to rule out Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). HUS is a form of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia usually occurring in children less than 5 years of age. HUS typically involves bloody diarrhea, hemolytic anemia, and kidney injury, which this child does not exhibit.

 

Other Options:

 

  • HUS (Option 2) is excluded due to the absence of bloody diarrhea and hemolytic anemia, which are typical features.
  • Severe dehydration (Option 1) is likely due to vomiting and diarrhea, leading to altered sensorium.
  • Cerebral venous thrombosis (Option 3) is a possible complication in severely dehydrated patients, leading to altered consciousness.
  • Hyponatremia (Option 4) can also be a consequence of prolonged diarrhea and vomiting, causing electrolyte imbalances and leading to neurological symptoms such as altered sensorium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The differential diagnoses of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium in a child include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia, while HUS is usually associated with bloody diarrhea and is ruled out in this case.

questions.text: Identify the structures shown in the images: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpora amylacea

 

The image shows corpora amylacea, which are spherical laminated hyaline structures commonly seen in elderly males in the prostate and represent a normal aging change. These are glycoprotein deposits that appear as round, concentrically laminated, eosinophilic (pink) structures with a glassy appearance. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus callosum: Incorrect. Corpus callosum is a broad band of nerve fibers that connects the two cerebral hemispheres in the brain. It would appear as white matter tracts in histological sections of brain tissue, not as concentric laminated structures seen in the image.

 

Option B. Psammoma body: Incorrect. Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated calcifications that appear as round, basophilic (blue) structures, typically found in certain neoplasms like meningiomas, papillary thyroid carcinoma, and serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. 

 

 

Option C. Corpus luteum: Incorrect. Corpus luteum is a temporary endocrine structure formed in the ovary after ovulation. Histologically, it would appear as a follicular structure with luteinized granulosa cells having abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The histological appearance of corpora amylacea, which are eosinophilic, concentrically laminated glycoprotein deposits that commonly occur in the prostate gland of elderly males as part of the normal aging process.

questions.text: Which fixation technique is used for fat in the histopathological examination? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frozen section

 

Identification of neutral lipids and fatty acids in smears and tissues may require fresh smears or sometimes cryostat sections of tissue. 

 

Rapid freezing makes the tissue sample firmer and ice acts as an embedding media allowing the tissue to be sectioned.

 

Cryostat machine temperature ranges from 0°C to -35°C. Most of the tissue can be sectioned between -15°C to -25°C. Tissue samples with high water content can be sectioned at a higher temperature. The tissues with high fat content are cut at a lower temperature.

 

The stain used for fat is the oil red O stain.

 

It is used in the following conditions:

 

  • Fat emboli in lung tissue
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Sebaceous gland tumors of the skin
  • Lipid-rich carcinomas

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IHC (Immunohistochemistry): This technique is used for detecting specific proteins within tissue sections but is not specifically used for fat preservation or visualization.

 

Option C. Liquid paraffin: Liquid paraffin is most commonly used for the fixation technique in the histopathological examination. It involves the fixation of tissues using formalin and subsequent embedding in paraffin wax. This technique allows for long-term preservation of tissue morphology and cellular details, making it the standard preservation procedure.

 

Option D. Formalin fixed: Formalin fixation is the standard method for preserving general tissue morphology but is not ideal for fat preservation, as it can dissolve lipid content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcoholic formalin is the most commonly used fixation technique for preserving and examining fat in histopathological sections.

 

Liquid paraffin is the most commonly used embedding agent.

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text:
Among the listed causes of alopecia, which one(s) result in non-scarring alopecia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

 

Non cicatricial alopecia classification:

 

 

Option 1 - Alopecia areata:

 

  • It is a persistent autoimmune condition characterized by non-scarring hair loss patches.
  • This inflammatory disease involves T cells and primarily affects individuals with genetic susceptibility, being associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.
  • The condition is identifiable by "exclamation mark hairs" – short, fragile hairs that taper toward the base, as illustrated in the image below.

 

 

  • Alopecia totalis refers to the complete loss of scalp hair.
  • Alopecia universalis involves the loss of all body hair.
  • In instances of limited alopecia areata, approximately 80% of patients experience spontaneous remission.
  • Alopecia areata predominantly affects pigmented hair.
  • In older individuals, gray hair may consist of both white and colored hair. If the disease progresses rapidly, only the colored hair will be affected and lost, leaving the white hair unaffected in the patches of hair loss.
  • This sudden change in hair color is known as "Turning white overnight".

 

The following image depicts sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Fig: Alopecia areata " Turning white overnight"

 

Option 2 - Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It is an acute onset of scalp hair loss that starts one to two months after a trigger, such as a high fever, infections (Cholera, Typhoid, Covid), trauma from surgery or other trauma, starvation, MI, Pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.
  • Telogen hair shedding that lasts longer than six months is known as chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency Anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition are the main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.

 

Option 3 - Androgenetic Alopecia

 

  • The disorder known as androgenetic alopecia is characterized by the miniaturization & reduction of hair follicle production.
  • Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are seen in male pattern hair loss.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option 4 - Frontal fibrosing alopecia

 

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows.
  • It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia’s do not destroy the hair follicle and allow for the possibility of hair regrowth.
  • Scarring alopecia’s involve destruction and replacement of the hair follicle with scar tissue, leading to permanent hair loss.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.25, 28, 33

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Online resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

choices.text: Activated protein C

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady had an uneventful vaginal delivery. On postpartum day 1, she presented with postpartum hemorrhage and complains of visual changes and severe headache. A few hours after the complaint, she is found to be in an unresponsive state and is intubated and put on ventilation. On further examination, she has a BP of 60/40 mmHg and tachycardia, blood sugar is 48 mg/dL. Hematocrit and WBC count was normal. Which of the following drugs would help reverse this state? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described—postpartum hemorrhage followed by severe headache, visual changes, hypotension, and unresponsiveness—suggests Sheehan syndrome. This condition arises from pituitary apoplexy, which is pituitary infarction secondary to severe blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

  • Sheehan Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland failure due to substantial blood loss during delivery. The symptoms include persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, lactation failure, headache, visual deficits, and in severe cases, shock, CNS hemorrhage, and even death.
  • Steroids: Hormone replacement with glucocorticoids (steroids) is crucial for managing Sheehan syndrome. Steroids address the adrenal insufficiency and help stabilize the patient’s condition. Initially, glucocorticoids are administered, followed by other hormone replacements as needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Dobutamine: Dobutamine is a beta-agonist used for managing cardiac failure and hypotension. While it may help with blood pressure, it does not address the underlying issue of pituitary failure and would not be the primary treatment for Sheehan syndrome.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone used in thyroid hormone replacement therapy. While it might be needed later if thyroid function is affected, it does not directly address the acute symptoms of Sheehan syndrome, which is primarily managed with steroids.

 

Option D. Activated Protein C: Activated protein C is used in the management of severe sepsis and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but it does not treat the pituitary dysfunction associated with Sheehan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is treated primarily with glucocorticoid (steroid) therapy to manage pituitary failure following significant blood loss during or after childbirth.

 

Ref: Page 378, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Clostridium difficile diarrhoea is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aminopenicillins

 

  • Clostridium difficile diarrhea is a super-infection also called as Pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Most common cause is 3rd generation Cephalosporins
  • Other causes include Clindamycin, Aminopenicillins (Ampicillin and Amoxycillin), and Fluoroquinolones.
  • DOC for treatment of PMC is fidaxomicin now.
  • Stool transplant can also be done.
  • Monoclonal antibody against toxin of C.difficile is Bezlotoxumab.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aminoglycosides: These can also lead to C. difficile diarrhea, but they are less commonly the cause compared to aminopenicillins and third-generation cephalosporins.

 

Option C. Macrolides: Macrolides are less likely to cause C. difficile diarrhea compared to aminopenicillins, third-generation cephalosporins, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones.

 

Option D. Carbapenems: Carbapenems are broad-spectrum antibiotics but are not commonly associated with C. difficile diarrhea. Their impact on the gut flora is less significant in this context compared to aminopenicillins and other antibiotics mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile diarrhea, also known as pseudomembranous colitis, is commonly associated with aminopenicillins such as ampicillin and amoxicillin.
