Treatment includes fidaxomicin and potentially stool transplants, with bezlotoxumab available as a monoclonal antibody against the toxin of C. difficile.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/744

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

 

High intraocular pressure leads to the thinning of the ocular tissue, thereby resulting in a staphyloma.

 

Staphyloma: It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera. So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

 

 

Ciliary and equatorial staphylomas are most commonly associated with glaucoma.

 

Types of Staphylomas     -

 

 

Note:

 

The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.

 

The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratoconus: This condition involves a progressive thinning and coning of the cornea, leading to visual distortion, but it is not typically associated with glaucoma.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia: A severe form of vitamin A deficiency leading to corneal softening. The association between keratomalacia and glaucoma is not typical, as keratomalacia results primarily from nutritional deficiencies.

 

Option D. Granular dystrophy: A type of corneal dystrophy characterized by the accumulation of granular deposits in the cornea. It is a genetically inherited condition, unrelated to the thinning caused by glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleate giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

In a patient with saddle nose deformity, septal perforation with pale granuloma and caseous necrosis on biopsy is consistent with tuberculosis (TB). The history of fever, cough, and hemoptysis along with cavitary lesions on chest x-ray supports the diagnosis of TB.

 

While other conditions like Wegener's granulomatosis (Option A), syphilis (Option C), and sarcoidosis (Option D) can also cause saddle nose deformity, the caseous necrosis on biopsy makes TB a more likely diagnosis.

 

Saddle-nose deformity refers to a depressed nasal dorsum that can involve either the bony, cartilaginous, or both components.

 

The most common cause is nasal trauma resulting in depressed fractures. Other causes include excessive submucosal resection, destruction of septal cartilage due to hematoma or abscess, and infections such as leprosy, tuberculosis, or syphilis, as well as inflammatory conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) and sarcoidosis.

 

Chronic granulomatous conditions such as lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can affect the cartilaginous part, syphilis primarily affects the bony part, and Wegener's granulomatosis and T-cell lymphoma can lead to total (bony and cartilaginous) septal destruction involving both the bony and cartilaginous portions.

 

TB is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and primarily affects the lungs but can also involve the nose and sinuses.

 

Common symptoms of TB include fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis. Chest x-ray often shows multiple cavitation lesions affecting the upper lobe and hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy findings in tuberculosis typically reveal granulomas, caseous necrosis, and multinucleate giant cells (Langhan's giant cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's granulomatosis: This can cause saddle-nose deformity and cavitary lesions, but biopsy would show necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis rather than caseous necrosis, which is seen in tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis can cause saddle-nose deformity, but typically affects the bony part of the nose, and biopsy would reveal gumma formation rather than the caseous necrosis seen in tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis can cause granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis typically associated with tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saddle-nose deformity with granuloma and caseous necrosis on biopsy is highly suggestive of tuberculosis.

choices.text: ACL and medial collateral ligament injury
Lateral collateral ligament injury
Medial meniscus injury

questions.text: The injury shown in the radiograph can result in: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ACL injury

 

SEGOND FRACTURE

 

  • Segond fracture is an avulsion fracture of the knee that involves the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau and is very frequently (»75% of cases) associated with disruption of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
  • On the frontal knee radiograph, it may appear as a curvilinear or elliptic bone fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau, referred to as the lateral capsular sign.

 

 

  • Contrary to the more common causes of an ACL tear, which typically involves valgus stress, a Segond fracture usually occurs as a result of internal rotation and varus stress.
  • Treatment:
  • Although the fracture itself is small, the extensive ligamentous injury associated with it usually requires surgical intervention.
  • Spontaneous healing of the Segond fracture may occur following ACL reconstruction.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows Segond fracture, which is frequently seen with ACL injuries.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymine

 

  • Deamination of methylated cytosine results in the conversion of cytosine to thymine. This process is important in DNA repair mechanisms and helps maintain the integrity of the genetic code. Thymine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and pairs with adenine in DNA base pairing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uracil: Uracil is not formed from the deamination of methylated cytosine. Uracil is one of the four standard nucleobases in RNA and is not a product of cytosine deamination.

 

Option B. Guanine: Guanine is another nucleobase and is not produced by the deamination of methylated cytosine.

 

Option C. Adenine: Adenine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and RNA and is not the product of cytosine deamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymine is a pyrimidine. The structure of different pyrimidines can be shown as:

 

 

Now, it is clear from the figure below that if methylated cytosine is deaminated it will form thymine as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 323

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are advantages of saline wet mount over iodine wet mount?

 

  1. Demonstration of motility of trophozoites
  2. Identify the internal structures of cysts
  3. Differentiate between bile and non-bile-stained eggs
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

 

The advantages of saline wet mount over iodine wet mount include its ability to demonstrate the motility of trophozoites and to differentiate between bile and non-bile-stained eggs.

 

  • Saline wet mount is an unstained preparation made using physiological saline, while iodine wet mount is prepared using diluted Lugol’s iodine or Dobell and O’Connor iodine solution.
  • Saline wet mount aids in visualizing the motility of trophozoites such as E. histolytica, Balantidium coli, and Giardia lamblia because it does not dry up as quickly as iodine wet mount.
  • It also helps differentiate between bile-stained and non-bile-stained eggs. Bile-stained eggs appear brown, while non-bile-stained eggs appear colorless. However, in iodine wet mounts, it is challenging to distinguish between bile-stained and non-bile-stained eggs because both appear stained brown.

 

Since iodine clearly stains the glycogen vacuoles and nuclei, the iodine wet mount helps in confirming the identification of cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Incorrect because iodine wet mount is better for identifying the internal structures of cysts due to its staining properties.

 

Option C. 2 and 3: Incorrect because saline wet mount does not effectively identify the internal structures of cysts compared to iodine wet mount.

 

Option D. 1, 2, and 3: Incorrect for the reasons mentioned above; statement 2 is not an advantage of the saline wet mount.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Saline wet mounts are particularly useful for demonstrating the motility of trophozoites and differentiating between bile and non-bile-stained eggs.

questions.text: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PT

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.

 

PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.

 

 

Causes of prolonged PT:

 

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
  • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)

 

Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.

 

Causes of prolonged APTT:

 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
  • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
  • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
  • Vitamin K deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time): APTT evaluates the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It measures the time taken for plasma to clot after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and calcium, but without tissue thromboplastin. APTT is used to assess the intrinsic pathway involving factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII, as well as the common pathway.

 

Option C. TT (Thrombin Time): TT measures the final step of the coagulation process—conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin after the addition of thrombin. It does not evaluate either the intrinsic or extrinsic pathways specifically but rather the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option D. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is a test that assesses platelet function and the initial phase of hemostasis but does not evaluate the coagulation pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade by measuring the time it takes for plasma to clot after the addition of tissue thromboplastin and calcium. It is commonly prolonged in conditions such as vitamin K deficiency, liver disease, and the use of vitamin K antagonists.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic Basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 232

choices.text: Both iris details and pupil margins are seen.
Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen.

questions.text: In the case of macular corneal opacity, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pupil margins are seen

 

Explanation: 


In macular corneal opacity, the iris details are not visible through the opacity, but the pupil margin can be easily seen. This is a key distinguishing feature of macular opacity compared to other types of corneal opacities. Macular opacity involves significant stromal injury but affects less than half the depth of the stroma. The opacity is easily visible but allows some visualization of deeper structures like pupillary margins.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Iris details are seen: This is incorrect. In macular opacity, the texture and details of the iris are obscured by the opacity.

 

Option C. Both iris details and pupil margins are seen: This is incorrect and better describes nebular opacity, which is the mildest form where both iris details and pupil margins are visible.

 

Option D. Both iris details and pupil margins are not seen: This is incorrect and describes leucomatous opacity, which is the densest form where neither iris details nor pupil margins are visible.

 

Educational Objective: 


Macular corneal opacity, pupil margins are visible while iris details cannot be seen - this is a key diagnostic feature that helps differentiate it from other types of corneal opacities.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducted a double-blind clinical trial comparing a new antidiabetic drug to a placebo. The study enrolled an equal number of participants in both arms. Based on the data below, what are the Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) and Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) for adverse effects? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RRR 11%, ARR 1%

 

Calculation -

 

  • Relative risk reduction (RRR): Percentage reduction in one outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Absolute risk reduction (ARR): Reduction in outcome (E.g. Death or Adverse outcome) comparing one group (New drug) with another group (Older drug or Placebo)
  • Event is taken as Occurrence of adverse outcome in the given example

 

In the given question,

 

Event rate Drug = 1603/15225 × 100 = 10.5% (0.105)

 

Event rate Placebo = 1804/15225 × 100 = 11.8% (0.118)

 

Hence,

 

  • Relative risk of Event rate = Event rate drug/Event rate Placebo = 0.105/0.118 = 0.9
  • Relative risk reduction (RRR) = (Event rate Placebo – Event rate drug)/Event rate placebo = (0.118)–0.105)/0.118 = 0.11 = 11%
  • Absolute risk reduction = Event rate Drug – Event rate Placebo = 0.105 – 0.118 = – 0.013 = – 1.3%

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Relative Risk Reduction (RRR) reflects the proportionate reduction in risk between two groups, while the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) provides the difference in risk between them

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In the given image of a post-mastoidectomy surgical field, label A corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal. The lateral semicircular canal is a crucial component of the inner ear's vestibular system, involved in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. It can be identified by its specific location relative to other anatomical landmarks visible in the image, such as the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This label points to the posterior semicircular canal, which is a bony protrusion in the mastoid portion of the temporal bone, serving as an important landmark during mastoid surgery.

 

Option C: This indicates the sigmoid sinus, a dural venous sinus within the skull, lying beneath the cranial bone and above the structures of the middle and inner ear.

 

Option D: Labelled as the Tegmen, which is part of the temporal bone that forms the roof over the middle ear and mastoid antrum, shielding these structures from the intracranial contents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was started on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient was later found unconscious at home and brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient shows signs of arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation. Which of the following does NOT suggest TCA poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Hypothermia is NOT typically associated with TCA poisoning. In fact, hyperthermia may occur due to anticholinergic effects leading to decreased sweating and heat dissipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, primarily due to their anticholinergic, sodium channel-blocking, and alpha-adrenergic blocking effects. The key features in this case would be:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias:

 

  • TCAs block sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction delays, which can manifest as arrhythmias. They can also cause QT prolongation, predisposing to torsades de pointes.
  • Therefore, arrhythmias are a common and significant feature of TCA poisoning.

 

Option B. Confusion:

 

  • The anticholinergic effects of TCAs can lead to mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and even delirium.
  • Confusion is a typical presentation in TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Pupillary Dilation:

 

  • Anticholinergic effects also include pupillary dilation (mydriasis) due to paralysis of the iris sphincter muscle.
  • Pupillary dilation is often observed in TCA toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is not a typical feature of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning, whereas arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation are common clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD with a swollen, red knee joint that is tender to touch. 2 weeks prior, he had an episode of fever with bloody diarrhea. Which of the following could be the possible organism? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shigella

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of reactive arthritis after shigella infection.

 

Shigellosis is a diarrheal infection caused by Shigella species—gram-negative, non-spore forming, facultative anaerobes that infect the intestinal lining—and spread by fecal-oral transmission.

 

Shigella species (eg, S dysenteriae, S flexneri, S sonnei, S boydii) are aerobic, nonmotile, glucose-fermenting, gram-negative rods that are highly contagious, causing diarrhea after ingestion of as few as 180 organisms.

 

These pathogens cause damage by two mechanisms, (1) invasion of the colonic epithelium, which is dependent on a plasmid-mediated virulence factor, and (2) production of an enterotoxin, which is not essential for colitis but enhances the virulence.

 

Symptoms of shigellosis include acute bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, tenesmus, urgency, fever, occasional vomiting and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E. coli: Certain strains of E. coli (such as EHEC) can cause bloody diarrhea and may lead to complications like Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), but reactive arthritis is less commonly associated with E. coli.

 

Option C. Giardia: Giardia typically causes watery diarrhea rather than bloody diarrhea and is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option D. Rotavirus: Rotavirus infection primarily causes watery diarrhea in young children and is not associated with bloody diarrhea or reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactive arthritis can occur following an infection with Shigella species, which is known for causing bloody diarrhea. This condition presents with joint inflammation and pain, typically occurring several weeks after the initial gastrointestinal symptoms.

 

Infection with Shigella species may be associated with extra gastrointestinal complications-

 

  1. Bacteremia
  2. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome characterized by acute hemolysis, renal failure, uremia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  3. Metabolic disturbances: Hyponatremia secondary to the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion may occur.
  4. Leukemoid reaction: An elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 50,000/mm3 occurs in approximately 4% of patients, mainly in children aged 2-10 years.
  5. Neurologic disease: Seizures, the most common neurologic complication.
  6. Encephalopathy with lethargy, confusion, and headache
  7. Reactive arthritis (also known as Reiter syndrome) may occur.

choices.text: Gently replace the cord inside the vagina
Inform the doctor and shift to OT
Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation

questions.text: A midwife is examining a pregnant woman in labour when she noticed that there is cord prolapse. What should be the next immediate step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put her in Trendelenburg position

 

Cord prolapse is an obstetric emergency where the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting part of the fetus in the birth canal, leading to compression of the cord. This compression can restrict blood flow and oxygen to the fetus, causing fetal distress or hypoxia.

 

The immediate management of cord prolapse includes:

 

  • Relieving pressure off the cord: This is crucial to prevent fetal hypoxia. This can be achieved by positioning the patient in a way that minimizes pressure on the cord.
  • Trendelenburg position: This position involves tilting the patient’s body with the head down and the pelvis up. This helps to shift the fetal presenting part off the prolapsed cord and relieves compression.
  • Left lateral position or All-fours position: Alternative positions can also help in relieving pressure on the cord.

 

While preparing for an emergency cesarean section (LSCS) to deliver the fetus urgently, these positions and techniques are used to temporarily alleviate the pressure on the cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gently replace the cord inside the vagina: Attempting to reposition the cord is not recommended as it can cause further damage or spasm of the vessels in the cord.

 

Option B. Inform the doctor and shift to OT: While informing the doctor and preparing for cesarean delivery is necessary, immediate steps to relieve cord compression should be taken first.

 

Option D. Do vaginal examination and find the fetal presentation: This may be done, but the primary focus should be on relieving the pressure on the cord immediately to prevent fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of cord prolapse, placing the patient in Trendelenburg position helps to relieve pressure on the prolapsed cord and is a critical step in managing the emergency until a cesarean section can be performed.

 

Ref: Page 1129, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The patient is dehydrated and the blood pressure of the patient is 90/60 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations revealed the serum potassium level of 6.0 mEq/L, sodium level of 129 mEq/L, and blood glucose level of 40 mg/dL. The patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for which he was prescribed medication by a local physician; however, the patient abruptly discontinued the medication a few weeks ago. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following drugs should be administered as a life-saving measure to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrocortisone

 

Hydrocortisone is indicated as it would treat adrenal insufficiency. It would help to correct hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia by replacing the deficient cortisol.

 

The clinical presentation of hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia in a patient who has suddenly stopped taking medication for RA (potentially a corticosteroid) suggests the possibility of adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis. This is particularly likely if the medication the patient was taking for RA was a corticosteroid, which is common in the management of RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis, which is not indicated in this case as there is no mention of acidosis in the given scenario.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin is used in the treatment of hyperkalemia to drive potassium into cells, but it would not address the underlying adrenal insufficiency and could potentially worsen the hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Hypertonic saline: Hypertonic saline is used to treat severe hyponatremia, which is not present in this case, as the sodium level is within normal limits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrocortisone is the drug of choice for treating adrenal insufficiency or Addisonian crisis, which can present with hypotension, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, dehydration, and hypoglycemia, especially in patients with a history of corticosteroid use who abruptly discontinue their medication.

questions.text: Match the Following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  1. Insulin - Tyrosine Kinase Pathway: Insulin uses a tyrosine kinase receptor. This is a cell surface receptor that, when activated, phosphorylates tyrosine residues on target proteins, triggering intracellular signaling cascades.
  2. Growth Hormone - JAK-STAT Pathway: Growth hormone, along with prolactin and leptin, uses the JAK-STAT (Janus Kinase-Signal Transducer and Activator of Transcription) pathway. This is a cytokine receptor-mediated signaling mechanism.
  3. Acetylcholine - Ligand-gated Channel: At the neuromuscular junction, acetylcholine operates through ligand-gated sodium channels. When acetylcholine binds, these channels open, allowing sodium ions to flow and triggering muscle contraction.
  4. Levothyroxine (Thyroid Hormone) - Nuclear Receptor: Thyroid hormones act through nuclear receptors, which means they enter the cell and directly interact with DNA in the nucleus to regulate gene expression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Classification of Receptors

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker presented with vague abdominal pain. On US, he was found to have a renal mass lesion. CECT was done, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Renal angiomyolipoma

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image presented here shows well-circumscribed lesions with low attenuation (black in color) that indicate fatty tissue. The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive angiomyolipoma. The presence of macroscopic fat within the lesion, which results in negative Hounsfield units on CT, is a key diagnostic feature of angiomyolipoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RCC (Renal Cell Carcinoma): Typically appears as a solid mass that may be hypervascular and can show necrosis but does not characteristically contain macroscopic fat.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Usually presents as a well-circumscribed, solid mass with a central scar, which is not visible in this image.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure without solid components, typically with very clear borders and no internal complexity or enhancement.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Z line
  2. M line
  3. A band
  4. H zone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

 

The proper order of bands within the sarcomere, moving from the periphery towards the center, is as follows: Z line - I band - A band - H zone - M line.

 

 

Z line: A dense protein structure that separates one sarcomere from the next and serves as an anchor for actin filaments.

 

I band: The light-colored region in a sarcomere composed of only thin actin filaments.

 

A band: The dark-colored region in a sarcomere containing both thick myosin and thin actin filaments.

 

H zone: The central part of the A band where only thick myosin filaments are present.

 

M line: The center of the sarcomere, providing structural support and anchoring the myosin filaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by Excessive contraction or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect because muscle direction is not detected by GTOs but rather involves the coordinated action of multiple muscles and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in the position of the muscle: Incorrect because muscle position is generally sensed by muscle spindles, not GTOs.

 

Option D. Sense changes in the length of the muscle: Incorrect because muscle length changes are detected by muscle spindles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Golgi tendon organ primarily functions to monitor and respond to changes in muscle tension, helping to prevent muscle damage from excessive force during activities.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia             

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VT is usually regular and wide QRS tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

 

Option B. P waves usually absent in AF.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia is regular narrow QRS tachycardia with fixed morphology of P wave.

 

Note:

 

  • MAT is usually associated with lung disease and occurs secondary to underlying hypoxemia.
  • Treatment is with CCB > BB to slow the atrial, ventricular rate.
  • Cardioversion is ineffective and contraindicated in this rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by multiple ectopic atrial activities leading to variable P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm, often associated with underlying chronic pulmonary conditions. Management focuses on treating the underlying condition and stabilizing the rate with appropriate medications.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/chap 250/7033

questions.text: The Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing which of the following conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe ulcerative colitis

 

The Truelove and Witt criteria are specifically used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis. These criteria help classify the disease into mild, moderate, or severe categories.


Another set of criteria called the Travis criteria is used to assess treatment response and predict the risk of progression to surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalitis: Incorrect because encephalitis has its own specific diagnostic criteria and severity assessment tools that focus on neurological symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. ARDS: Incorrect because ARDS is diagnosed and classified using the Berlin criteria (2012), which primarily use the P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) with a PEEP of at least 5 cm H2O.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect because acute pancreatitis has scoring systems for severity assessment, such as Ranson's criteria or the APACHE II score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis.

 

Truelove and Witt's Criteria for Severity of Ulcerative Colitis

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histamine  

 

The most important mast cell–derived amine is histamine. Histamine causes intense smooth muscle contraction, increased vascular permeability, and increased mucus secretion by nasal, bronchial, and gastric glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thromboxane A2: Thromboxane A2 is an activator of platelet aggregation and vasoconstrictor.

 

Option C. Serotonin: Serotonin possesses both vasoconstrictor and vasodilator properties.

 

Option D. Leukotrienes C4: Leukotrienes C4 and D4 are the most potent vasoactive and spasmogenic agents known. On a molar basis, they are several thousand times more active than histamine in increasing vascular permeability and causing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Leukotriene B4 is highly chemotactic for neutrophils, eosinophils, and monocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is the primary mediator responsible for causing vasodilation, playing a critical role in the inflammatory response by increasing blood flow and vascular permeability.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Metastatic calcification except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with Hypercalcemia (Vitamin D toxicity), not Vitamin D deficiency.

 

 

Tumors having Dystrophic calcification: Psammoma bodies present

 

M – Meningioma, Mesothelioma

 

O – Ovary (Serous cystadenoma)

 

S – Salivary gland tumor

 

T – Thyroid (Papillary thyroid cancer)

 

P – Prolactinoma

 

G – Glucagonoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal failure: Chronic kidney disease can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia, both of which contribute to hypercalcemia and subsequent metastatic calcification.

 

Option B. Accumulation of calcium phosphate: This typically occurs in the context of renal failure or parathyroid hormone-related issues, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Option D Parathyroid activation secretion: Hyperparathyroidism, whether primary or secondary, causes an increase in serum calcium, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with conditions that lead to hypercalcemia, not with conditions that result in normal or low calcium levels, such as Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the neck undergoes radical neck dissection. Which of the following structures is typically spared during this procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digastric muscle

 

Radical neck dissection spares the digastric muscle.

 

  • The digastric muscle is typically spared during a radical neck dissection. This muscle is important for several functions, including swallowing and jaw movement.
  • Preservation of the digastric muscle helps maintain normal swallowing and chewing abilities, which is essential for a patient's quality of life postoperatively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A radical neck dissection is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of lymph nodes level 1 to 5, ipsilateral submandibular gland and tail of parotid, as well as other structures in the neck such as the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve.

 

In modified radical neck dissections, some structures may be spared, such as the internal jugular vein, sternocleidomastoid muscle or the spinal accessory nerve.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Temperature

 

Feed forward control system is employed during regulation of temperature.

 

This is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Such a system is called Feed forward or Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement. Therefore, the brain uses a principle called feed-forward control to cause required muscle contractions wherein sensory nerve signals from the moving parts inform the brain whether the movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscles the next time the movement is required. Then, if still further correction is needed, this will be done again for subsequent movements. This is called adaptive control.

 

Examples include:

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • Thinking about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Motor coordination by cerebellum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood volume: Incorrect. The regulation of blood volume is primarily a feedback mechanism based on circulating blood volume and blood pressure.

 

Option B. pH: Incorrect. pH regulation in the body involves feedback mechanisms that monitor and adjust to changes in hydrogen ion concentration.

 

Option D. Blood pressure: Incorrect. While there are anticipatory aspects in blood pressure regulation during activities like exercise, it's primarily governed by feedback mechanisms responding to changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The feed forward control system is a preemptive regulatory mechanism employed notably in temperature regulation, allowing the body to anticipate environmental changes and adjust physiological responses in advance to maintain homeostasis.

questions.text: Vitamin K in its coenzyme form is regenerated by the enzyme? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epoxide reductase

 

Vitamin K plays a crucial role in the carboxylation of glutamic acid residues in proteins to form gamma-carboxyglutamate, which is important for blood clotting. The active form of vitamin K is required for this carboxylation reaction. After participating in the carboxylation reaction, vitamin K is converted to its epoxide form. To be reused, this epoxide form must be converted back to its active hydroquinone form.

 

The enzyme epoxide reductase is responsible for this conversion. It reduces vitamin K epoxide back to the active hydroquinone form, thus regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K. This process is essential for the continuous availability of active vitamin K for carboxylation reactions.

 

 

Fig: Vitamin K cycle.

 

Dicoumarol - a structural analog inhibits vitamin K reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutathione reductase: This enzyme is involved in the reduction of glutathione disulfide to glutathione, and is not involved in the regeneration of vitamin K.

 

Option B. Quinone reductase: This enzyme reduces quinones to hydroquinones but is not specifically responsible for the regeneration of vitamin K's active form.

 

Option C. Vitamin K reductase: While it plays a role in the vitamin K cycle, the specific enzyme responsible for regenerating the coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form is epoxide reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epoxide reductase regenerates the active coenzyme form of vitamin K from its epoxide form, ensuring the continuous availability of active vitamin K for critical carboxylation reactions.

questions.text: Which one of the following curves shows oxygen Hb dissociation after transfusion of stored blood: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve after transfusion of stored blood is characterized by two key factors:

 

  1. Low 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) levels
  2. Lower temperature of stored blood

 

These factors cause a left shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which is represented by curve B. The left shift means hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen, making it more difficult to release oxygen to tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.

questions.text: Identify the structure indicated by the arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.
